transcript.title: NVIDIA CORPORATION, ET AL., Petitioners, v. E.  OHMAN J:OR FONDER AB, ET AL., Respondents

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument this morning in Case 23-970, NVIDIA versus Ohman J:or Fonder AB. Mr. Katyal.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The Reform Act's pleading standards are unique.
Congress looked at priv ate securities litigation and saw big fishing expeditions in discovery and extortion at settlements.

They knew that for centuries, heightened pleading had been required, but they super-charged it. First, they required plaintiffs to "state with particularity" facts giving rise to a strong inference the defendant acted with scienter, a dramatic break with common law, and, second, they required, for allegations outside of a plaintiff's personal knowledge, plaintiffs to "state with particularity all the facts on which their belief is formed."  This double -heightened pleading requirement exists in virtually no other context.
Y2K is the lone example, and that is what resolves this case. As our cert petition and the amici explain, the Ninth Circuit's decision creates an easy roadmap for plaintiffs to evade the Reform Act.

When a stock drops, all they have to do is find an expert with numbers that contradict a company's public statements, then allege the company keeps records that executives look at, and then argue those records would have matched the hired expert's numbers. That's a recipe for Judge Friendly's warning of fraud by hindsight. This complaint, which alleges that Jensen Huang made false statements, is a good example.
It's a grave accusation against a respected CEO.
Yet the complaint never shows his scienter to be as cogent and compelling as not.

It merely surmises that Huang reviewed internal reports showing a higher quantum of crypto purchases than what he disclosed, yet it never alleges the contents of those reports. And to meet falsity, the complaint relies on an expert opinion with a series of implausible assumptions and inferences, not particularized allegations of fact.
Nothing dispels the more compelling explanation that Huang offered at the time.
He knew crypto buys were increasing prices, and so he introduced a crypto -specific chip and increased the supply of gaming chips with the hopes that prices would fall.

The fact this process took longer than anticipated is not securities fraud. The Ninth Circuit slighted the Act's heightened pleading requirements, and this Court should reverse. I welcome the Court's questions.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What would this complaint look like if it had complied with the heightened pleading standards?
Yeah.

So I think it would have had to allege  -- this complaint is based on internal documents, and so it would have to allege the contents of those documents, and particularly, Justice Thomas, for example, it would have to answer what specific data did the CEO actually see, how clear was it, when did he see that data.

Was the data generated after his public statements or before? How much does that data deviate from the public statements?  Where does that data cover?  Is it one country?  Is it the world?  And, you know, when was that data generated?  So, you know, what did the CEO know, when did he know it, I think are the most important questions. And, here, when you scratch just below the surface -- and this is what Judge Sanchez's dissent, I think, so powerfully did or the district court did -- by going allegation by allegation, it all dissolves.
It's certainly a long complaint.
I'll give -- I'll spot them that.
But it's a long complaint like cotton candy that dissolves after -- it looks like a lot of volume, but it dissolves.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Katyal, I  --I guess my concern is that you appear to be requiring for plaintiffs to actually have the evidence in order to plead their case, and I didn't understand the pleading standards, even with particularity, to require that they have the documents, nor do I understand how they could have the documents when discovery hasn't occurred yet.
So -- so, of course, they do have documents.
In this very case, Joint Appendix 59 to 62 does provide an internal document.
It's a document that entirely backfires on them --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, I understand.
--as to the  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But  --but the typical plaintiff  --
Sure.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- in a situation like this -- MR.
KATYAL:  Sure.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- because the company has the documents  --
Sure.
So I just wanted to say factually  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
-- and, of course, the SEC had access to all the documents and found -- never found scienter, but  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right, but the SEC is not pleading this case.
Of course, of co urse.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We have plaintiffs --
Absolutely.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- who are bringing these allegations, and you're right that  they reference documents, that documents are important to their claim of scienter.

But I guess the standard that I hear you wanting us to require would cause them to have to have such level of detail about the contents of the documents that it would seem that they would need to have the documents, right?
So, Justice Jackson, we don't think that's right.
That's not our legal standard. Our blue brief at page 40 is express about that.
Our point is that the document -- that the contents can be met by someone who has the documents or who has personally reviewed those documents and describes them with particularity.
And so we'd say look to, for example, the ABC case from the Fifth Circuit.
In that case, it said, look, you don't  -- there were -- they didn't have the documents, but they had details about the documents.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But why are the details necessary in certain cases?  I mean, part of my concern is that you seem to be wanting a bright line that says the contents of the documents are necessary, and I can imagine a number of scenarios in which that might not be the case. So we have someone -- for example, many employees who are at a board meeting, many board meetings during the relevant period of time.
They say memos were circulated with regularity talking about this kind of thing.

We can't remember exactly the data points, but the discrepancy between what was -- the CEO was saying publicly and what was appearing in the documents  that we were reviewing was glaring, and we remember that, and we know that.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I don't understand why that's not enough for the pleading stage.
Right.
So, Justice Jackson, our point  --our -- our rule is definitely not that you have to have the documents.
And some cases won't need documents at all.
So, for -- you know, our brief goes through a lot of real -world examples, like the Glazer case, in  which the employees say the boss was ordering us to cook the books.
Or, if you have a circumstance like Stevelman, in which a boss is handed a report, we don't know what that report says, but right after the handing of the report, the boss goes and sells stock.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no, no.
My hypothetical is we do know what it said.
We knew what it said at the time, says the employees.
What we don't remember for today in this moment, as we are alleging, exactly what the data points were, but --
Yeah.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- we  --we -- our testimony is that documents that we saw that had the relevant information were given to the CEO during this meeting at the same time that the CEO was saying something else externally.
Yeah.
And if those documents  --you know, if they --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why  --why do we need the data points, is my question.
Well, the data is  --is a requirement of what particularity is.
Particularly -- particularity requires some -- you know, at least a good description of the who, what, where, when, and how.
That's what Congress required.
And, yes, sometimes  --you're absolutely right --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Katyal  --
-- that will --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- could I stop you a moment?  Tell me what rule you want us to adopt.
Yeah.
So, if a plaintiff is relying on an allegation to show an inference of scienter, it has to be particularized enough to know whether it is truly relevant to establishing scienter.
So, in a case like this  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, you know something, it  --it sounds to me -- and I am concerned about your cert petition because you made two allegations in your cert petition.
The first one was similar to this, but you said you wanted a bright-line rule that you need to have particularized X description of the document.

That's what you said in your -- in your cert petition. But Tellabus -- Tellabs, our case, alleged that the CEO knew or should have known that the company's internal sales reports were not consistent with its public statements, but they did not allege the precise contents of those reports.
We rejected the petitioner's argument there that the plaintiff failed to describe the documents in enough detail. It's an issue of fact.
Is there enough detail? Now you're spotting us that it's a very long complaint.
We often don't grant cert to error-correct.
Is this entire case just an error correction?
Oh, absolute  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: These particular documents are not precise enough?  I'm not actually sure what rule we could articulate that would be clearer than our cases already say.
Yeah.
So, absolutely, this, we don't think, is.
That's, of course, what my friend on the other side tried to argue.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, except that I've gone through the complaint, all right, and we have any number of employees, some of them who created the documents, others who were present when the documents were being discussed, others who -- only one who wasn't present during the relevant time but who set up what the creation of the documents showed, and others who were present during the time who said there were many, many crypto sales, many more than the $150 million that your client claimed, and he kept saying that it was a small part of the business, all right? And yet all of these employees are saying, no, it's not a small part of the business.
One of them was familiar with China, and it was a huge part of China's business.
And others were familiar with Europe.
I -- I -- I guess I'm going back to this is pure error correction that you're asking us to do.
So, Justice Sotomayor, there's a lot there, so I have a lot to say in response. So, first of all --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Tell me your rule.

So I told you the rule, which is, if they are basing their allegations and inferences of scienter on internal documents, they have to disclose those documents with particularity. Now my friend on the other side in the brief in opposition said that's just fact-bound error correction.
This Court granted certiorari over that and I think for good reason.
This case is very much like the Twombly case, in which Justice Stevens --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, it's because you --
-- made exactly --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- because you told us there was a 5-to-2 split.
And, in fact, there is no split.
None of the cases you cited in the split hold the rule that you're claiming.
I think they do, Justice Sotomayor.
So, for example  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.

Two of them -- the Second Circuit and the Anderson case, which is the only one in your merits brief that you go through, that case was the court simply saying the witness was talking to us about one thing in the reports but not about the scienter that was necessary for the second thing.

If I could contrast what -- the case that I just gave Justice Jackson, the Fifth Circuit decision in ABC, which goes through a long complaint and says at the end of it, a hundred pages, 14 confidential witnesses, all of that together doesn't actually state a claim because it's not particularized, and you match that up against the Ninth Circuit, it is, you know, as clear as day that these are two very different approaches. This Court in Tw ombly confronted a similar situation, and the district court dismissed a case for failing to state a claim.
The Second Circuit reversed.
Justice Stevens made exactly the arguments you are in dissent, and he said, look, you know, the law is as clear as day.
But this Court remand -- didn't just remand, it reversed and said the Second Circuit was wrong, we need to set a standard for the entire country to avoid lawsuits from going on.
And I think Twombly is a very good example of how the Court's setting that rule matters. This Court has never defined particularity since the year 1926.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right, counsel  --
This case provides a good explanation.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- one last thing on your expert rule.
Yeah.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your expert rule sounds very much like Justice Alito's concurrence.
Is it?
No.

We  --we don't -- we certainly don't have any objection to Justice Alito's concurrence in Tellabs, but we don't think, as our reply brief says, it matters here. So, Justice Sotomayor, you were talking about all the employees' statements.
All the employees' statements taken together never get to where they need to go, which is a strong inference that shows that  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm -- I'm -- I'm totally dubious of that, but your other side can get you the factual argument on that because I've read through the allegations, and the employees were talking about constant sales reports that tracked every item that was being sold either to a gamer or to a cryptocurrency marketeer, and they were talking about the exact nature of the documents that were being created and the fact that there were many, many more sales than the 150 million that he was claiming.
So -- so, Justice Sotomayor, with all respect, the district court went through allegation by allegation of these former employees and decimated each one, showing none of them were particularized.
I understand what they've done is throw a bunch of spaghetti at the wall, and it's very hard for me in a half -hour argument to deal with that kind of shell game.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Could we go to the  --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Counsel, one thing that concerns me about both sides' presentation, it's a little black and white.
I gather you wouldn't be terribly upset about a complaint with a lot of direct evidence and, you  know, some expert reports that sort of help shore that up.

And I'm assuming the other side would be fine if -- if it -- you know, the balance was -- was the other way. Now, if I think that the positions on both sides are a little too absolute, how do you find sort of the sweet spot in terms of when the PSLRA is satisfied?  I mean, it can't be just a little bit of direct evidence because that statute was intended to do something.

On the other hand, it seems to me you can't insist on only the direct evidence before a complaint goes forward. So, if -- if I don't think it's black and white, how do  --what -- how do I decide where the balance is?
So, Mr. Chief Justice, you adopt the rule that's in our brief, which is not that you need direct evidence.
Circumstantial evidence can do that just as well.

I t's just got to be particularized, and at the end of the day, it's got to meet that Tellabs holistic inquiry of showing scienter is at least as cogent and compelling as not. So I think, at a minimum, it's going to require what specifically did the CEO know and when did he know it. This case is a perfect illustration.
All the evidence Justice Sotomayor is pointing to is from outside the class period, from before the class period.
As our brief explains, in May of 2017, which is the beginning of the class period, that's a watershed moment.

Why?  Because, at that moment, the company introduces a crypto-specific chip, the Crypto SKU. And what their own complaint says -- the only time they allege an internal document is at Joint Appendix 59 to 62, and that document boomerangs on them.

It shows, once that new chip was introduced, crypto sales to  --to miners, to GPU sales, dropped dramatically, down to 27 percent from 62 percent. So the complaint essentially eats itself. This is why particularity is so important, why Congress insisted on it, that when question, because when they have a bunch of data  --a bunch of allegations from before May of 2017, that tells us nothing about after that.
It's kind of like looking at BlackBerry sales data before the introduction of the iPhone and saying, look, we can project BlackBerry sales after the iPhone's  -- after the iPhone's introduction.
Of cours e not. The whole thing the company was doing here, they were acknowledging that crypto miners were buying their products.
They said, look, we couldn't track exactly h ow much.
They introduced a whole product to deal with that.
Their allegation is this CEO lied and lied about the dependence on crypto. I mean, it's a really weird way to lie to say we're going to introduce a whole new product to deal specifically  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But, Mr.
-- with this market.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- Mr. Katyal, your -- your description and your discussion and your argument sounds to me like summary judgment stage kind of discussion.

In other words, you -- you seem to be suggesting that this is the evidence that they have related to your, you know, client's misconduct and it's not enough. And I would appreciate that if we were at the summary judgment stage.

What I don't understand is, at the pleading stage, the allegations being made, how you are saying what I understood your rule to be as stated in your question presented is there the contents of the documents have to be alleged with particularity.
And I'm still stuck on that as a -- the only way in which a plaintiff can sufficiently allege scienter in this kind of circumstance.
I don't know why that is.
Yeah.
So, again, it's not the only way.
There's lots of ways in which people allege non-document cases.
So the executive says cook the books.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, I'm saying in a documents case.
In a documents case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In a documents case --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- you can have a world in which you're not necessarily quoting from  --
Agreed.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- pointing to the contents.
A hundred percent agree.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And yet your rule suggests that that case would have to be dismissed --
Not at all.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- because it's not particularized.
No.
You've just got to --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So I'm misunderstanding your rule.
Right.
You  -- you -- you certainly don't need to have the document, quote from the document.
You do have to disclose the particulars of what that document says.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So can I ask you a  -- give you a couple hypotheticals to test what that means? First hypothetical, you have a complaint that alleges that on Monday, the CEO tells a few subordinates:  I just read this -- these internal documents and it looks like sales of our principal product are down. And then, on Tuesday, he goes out and tells the public:  Sales of our principal product are up.
Yeah.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that particularized enough?
Yes.
You don't need to have the report.
That's very much like what happened in Tellabs on remand.
Absolutely.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.

So sort of just a statement, you know, I'm not giving you numbers, I'm not giving you a lot of, you know, this document -- this -- this product did one thing and this product did one -- another thing.
I'm just saying sales were down, sales were up.
I don't think you need quantity.
I do think you need to show a deviation, a delta, between the public statements and what the CEO knew, and so  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
Sales were down and sales were up.
Yeah.
So, I mean, down and up, you know, is enough gravity.
Yes, that could be -- that could state a claim.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.

Suppose that the document  -- excuse me  --the complaint doesn't have these --these allegations that he said something about the documents to a bunch of subordinates, but, instead, it's  --it  --it's  --he has made the same public statement, sales are up, and the plaintiffs come up with a lot  -- and -- and -- and the plaintiffs come up with a lot of evidence that shows two things. The first is that he constantly reads documents about sales, all right, and the second is they come up with a lot of sort of outside evidence that sales were, in fact, down.
So they don't have him saying "I read the document and the document says X," but there's a lot of evidence that really indicates that the document said X because that's the evidence in the world.
Yeah.
So, again, I think it's what did the CEO know and when did he know it.
In your hypothetical, the when question is answered in a way that it's not at all with all the allegations in this case.
So we have no idea when the CEO got that information. In your case, I think it's possible to infer based on everything that the CEO might have had access to that information and did it.
Here, you've got a very different circumstance because you've got a product which is just a component in which they can't track end users.
The only allegation that --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So --
--they tracked end users is -- is --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- as I hear what you're saying, you're not really saying that you have to -- I mean, you're -- you know, that you have to have the -- the contents of those documents, as long as what the complaint alleges, yo u know, and plausibly so, is that he stares at a lot of documents and the evidence suggests that the documents would have said something that's quite different from what he presents to the public.
You've got to describe  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And so that's not -- you know, that's good for you and that's bad for you. That's not a bright-line rule, and that's good for you because we don't like bright -line rules in this context and have said so a thousand times. But it's bad for you because, as the -- as -- as what you're saying from the podium in terms of the rule you think we should adopt gets more and more like the sort of thing that we usually ask for, it becomes less and less clear why we took this case, number one, as Justice Sotomayor suggested, and, number two, why you should win it.
Right.
So our rule has always been the same.

We've always said it's not a bright-line rule, that it's a contextual rule, contextualized rule, and one in which you are to ask, you know, have the particulars been disclosed?  And what we're basically seeking is a definition of particularity. In this case, that would mean at least answering what that data was that showed a deviation from the CEO's public statements and what he knew. And there's nothing even close.
And the complaint at best just eats itself.
So you don't need to ask for evidence, as Justice Jackson was saying, or anything else.
You just need the complaint itself and -- and then ask was any of the allegations showing enough of a delta, because this is a quantum case.
The company is disclosing all over the place they sell to crypto miners.
The question is what the extent of that was and was that something that was a deviation.
We think this is a --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Katyal, why isn't that error correction,  though?  I mean, kind of returning to Ms.

-- to Justice Sotomayor's point, if we think your bright-line rule fails for the reasons Justice Kagan is suggesting, why isn't your answer that you're giving Justice Kagan simply asking us to go through the complaint and explain why it's not good enough?
We -- we think that it's not error correction because the Ninth Circuit's rule was too loosey-goosey and allowed basically a recipe for fraud by hindsight every time this  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it articulated the rule as we said it in Matrixx and Tellabs.
No, I -- I think it didn't articulate the rule.
So let me just give you one example.
Tellabs says the key inquiry is a comparative one to look at all -- whether or not their story is as cogent and compelling as any competing inferences.
Did the big tell here, did the Ninth Circuit ever even bother engaging in that?  No, because there weren't the details that they provided --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, they did say --
--to do so.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- they did say that -- on that, they did say, Mr. Katyal, that it  -- it -- it -- it beggars belief to think that a CEO would not have been aware --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- of the source of such a large portion of the company's income --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- especially given the evidence here that this CEO was very interested in sales channel data.
Yes.
So four things --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And so why -- so why -- you may disagree with that comparative conclusion, but why isn't that a comparative conclusion?
So, Justice Gorsuch, four things.
We absolutely agree with you.
Petition Appendix 55a, that is what the court says -- the Ninth Circuit says.
They say it's reasonable to infer Huang would review the documents because a CEO who does not know the source of 1.2 billion in revenues is unlikely to exist.

There are several things about that. Number one, that never even acknowledges our competing story and our competing inference that the company couldn't track those revenues because that data doesn't exist.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, but that -- that -- that is acknowledged elsewhere in the opinion and it may be not emphasized enough for your taste and  -- and, therefore, may be wrong as a matter of error correction.
But there is a comparative analysis that was performed.
And  --and that comparative analysis depends entirely -- that number, 1.2, comes entirely from that expert, Prysm --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Again --
-- which had all the pro blems.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- might be wrong, but there's a comparative analysis.

Comparative analysis, absolutely, but, Justice Gorsuch, it's notable that our brief at pages 45 to 47 describes all of the problems with that report and they don't even bother and the government doesn't even bother trying to defend those assumptions  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Let me ask you a question on --
--or the fact it's required.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- on that while I've got you and then I'll let you go.
I promise. Do you take the position of Professor Grundfest that an expert opinion can never be used to help establish particularized facts?
No, no, no.
We say that expert opinions can't be used to substitute for those facts, which is the rule of the Second and Fifth Circuits, and we think  the Court should embrace that rule.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So it can be used to supplement them --
To supplement.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- like any other circumstantial evidence?
Yeah, exactly.
Yeah.
It c an be -- you know, the facts underlying absolutely can be.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
Now, to get back to the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
-- point about the comparative inference  -- oh.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, counsel. I -- I just have one question about an analogy.
I  -- I guess maybe I -- I don't -- I've never heard the analogy the complaint eats itself. What -- what does that mean? (Laughter.)
What I'm trying to say  --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's very vivid, but I don't know  --
I'm trying to basically illustrate to Justice Jackson you don't  -- we're not -- our rule is not one about evidence.

It's rather read the complaint and ask that Tellabs inquiry:  Is it as cogent and compelling as the alternative explanation? Here, the alternative explanation is the company saw crypto price -- the GPU prices were high, and they dealt with it through the introduction of a crypto-specific chip. Prices didn't fall as quickly as they thought.
Sometimes that happens in markets where retailers keep prices high.
But there's nothing to say that the CEO lied about it. And what I say by "eats its influence"  -- "eats itself," this is what Justice  -- Judge Sanchez said at page 87a in his dissent.
He looked at paragraph 121 in the complaint, and paragraph 121 shows that watershed moment in May of 2017.

When the company introduces that new chip, GPU sales to miners fall dramatically. And so, if you just read the complaint, it doesn't even state a plausible for a 12(b)(6) theory, let alone one that meets the Reform Act, because the Reform Act requires so much more what Mr. Huang knew and when he knew it.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
I'm not sure how that's eating itself, but I'll take your word.
Destroys itself, whatever word you want to use.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Thomas? Justice Alito?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, let me go back to the Prysm report.

Would you dispute the proposition that if the discrepancy between what Mr. Huang stated and the figures in the Prysm report were true, that the inference drawn by the Ninth Circuit would be a legitimate inference at the 12(b)(6) stage?

So, Justice Alito, if the report disclosed the methodology, how it got there, as opposed to relying on "proprietary data" that they never tell us, and was able to surmount all of the problems that  --that -- the big, huge gaps in inference that our brief details, like, for example, it treated every increase in processing power as the result of an NVIDIA new chip, you know, as if there was no delay between sales and adding to the network, if it, you know, didn't treat crypters and -- crypto miners and gamers as different people when they're often the same, if  you jumped through all that, yes, we think a report like that could be helpful. But, in this case, it's miles and miles away from that.
This is a report that, you know, yes, they went to Harvard, but, beyond that, I don't think it can tell you very much about the state of reality of the world.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I don't really understand how you and perhaps your  -- your friend think that reports like this, opinions by experts on a highly technical subject,  are supposed to be handled at the 12(b)(6) stage. The facts that Prysm relied on are set out with some particularity, are they not?

So they  --there are some with particular -- some indicia of particularity, but at the end of it, no, because, for example, it relies on a proprietary model they don't even tell us about. Our problem here is not, Justice Alito, that --we think a  -- you know, you can have an expert come in to explain a complicated term or something like that, but this expert was creating an entire economic model to estimate NVIDIA's crypto sales because that data didn't exist anywhere else.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
And you  --
That's what they're paying them for.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- and -- and you claim, and you -- maybe you're right, that the model is flawed, the data is not reliable.

But this is a highly technical subject, and I just don't understand how a court is supposed to evaluate that at the pleading stage. You talk about Daubert, but Daubert is not a case that sets out a standard to determine whether a complaint -- whether a -- a claim should be dismissed at that  --at that stage. So what --what is  --what is a court to do at the pleading stage when it is presented with highly technical information that is beyond the capability of a judge to evaluate at that stage? It's different at that stage than at trial, when there --there's an opportunity to have a cross-examination  --
So we --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- of the expert, qualify the expert, ask the expert questions.
It's a puzzling question to me.
Yeah.

So, Justice Alito, we think the U.S. Government has it right at page 34. The defendants may "challenge an expert's reliance  on conclusory, speculative premises at the pleading stage." Now, in a case like this, in which it's not that type of such difficult thing for a court to analyze by reading the report and seeing all of the gaps and noting, most tellingly, that they can't even bother trying to defend the analysis of the expert, that's an easy case. In your very complicated, you know, technical case in which a court can't evaluate one way or another, you know, we don't have a position on that because that's just miles away from this case. We think you should leave that to one side.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
Well, one more question along these lines. You draw a distinction between fact and opinion.
But isn't it true that it is a fact that Prysm reached certain conclusions?  Is that not a particularized fact?
No.
We don't think that -- at least relevant particularized fact.
It's how they got to those conclusions.

And their methodology in that report's not disclosed. My friend on the other side says, oh, okay, don't look at Prysm, look at the RBC report, which is one sentence in their complaint. The Ninth Circuit doesn't rely on it. Nobody does because that doesn't disclose the methodology at all.
It's literally one  sentence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Sotomayor? Justice Kagan?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If I understood your answers to Justice Alito, you're not suggesting that there's any special rule relating to expert evidence, expert reports.
You're just saying that this was a terribly flawed report, is that correct?
Correct.

We're saying you adopt the Second and Fifth Circuits' rule that an expert opinion can't itself substitute for particularized allegations of fact. You treat it just like the government does. Pretend that the statement wa s made by a plaintiff, was made by a plaintiff  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah, I mean, once again, it just seems to me that you're asking us to engage in a kind of analysis that we are not very good at and weren't expecting to when we took this case, to decide whether this particular report is flawed or not in the way that you suggest.

Justice Kagan, I think our position has been exactly the same in the cert petition, and it's  -- you know, I think the reason you have to do it and reverse the Ninth Circuit is what -- what Judge Sanchez said in dissent, which is, otherwise, you've given every plaintiff a how-to roadmap:  Hire an expert like this, say it's really complicated, along the lines of Justice Alito's questions  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you think that the Royal Bank of Canada report is flawed in the same way?
I have no idea because it's one sentence and doesn't even tell us how it reached anything, as  -- as Professor --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what do -- what do you -- I mean, presumably, it's out there in the world, right?  Presumably, you've read it --
The one sentence.
Yeah, the one sentence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- the Royal Bank of Canada report --
Yeah.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- which concluded that NVIDIA understated its crypto -related revenues by more than a billion dollars.
Yes.
So it's one sentence. And, Justice Kagan  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The report is not one sentence, is it?

The analysis is, yeah. There's nothing there. And as Professor Grundfest says in his brief, it very well may be that the RBC report is relying on the same proprietary data, the Petty data, as the Prysm report.
It might be double-counting the very same report.
And this is why, Justice Kagan --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But, again, it's --
-- particularity matters.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But, again, you're  -- you're -- you're not saying that it's -- we shouldn't -- it --it doesn't go into the mix because it's an expert report in any way.
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's just like:  What was that based on?  Is that a good report?
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is the -- is the Prysm report a good report?  Is any other report that they can come up with a good report? That's what you're asking us to evaluate.

So I  --I quite agree, except I wouldn't just say "good."  I would say disclose the particulars, how you got there, and  -- and make sure that there aren't unwarranted assumptions. The one thing we know  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
--the Prysm report has lots of -- a series of unfounded assumptions.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Gorsuch?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So we've talked about how the case has kind of migrated from the first QP into more fact-intensive questions for us, and I'm wondering whether that's, after your discussion with Justice Kagan, where we are on the second QP, which was whether a plaintiff can satisfy the PSLRA's particularity requirement by relying on an expert report to substitute for particularized allegations of fact. And what I'm hearing today is, well, sometimes an expert report might be able to do that if it itself is particularized.
And this one is not. It's not a categorical rule that expert reports are off the table.

It's  --it's the same ru le, Justice Gorsuch, as in our cert petition, which is that in expert opinions, facts, the underlying facts, can help state a  -- can --can state a claim, but the very credentials and the fact that an expert offers an opinion cannot. The Ninth Circuit at pages 20 to 23 relied on the expert's credentials to jump past all of the problematic assumptions.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I understand  --
And so --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- I understand your concerns very well with respect to this report, but it does strike me that there's some delta between what you're asking us to do today and what your QP 2 says.

No, I think it's the same basic point, which is, you know, expert opinions can't substitute for those underlying facts. And we think it's important the Court reach that for the reason Judge Sanchez said, because, otherwise, this decision is a how-to map:  Hire an expert, say that expert's really credentialed, say it's a really complicated issue, and jump past Congress's --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.

But, if  --if we had a really robust report here that you really couldn't take issue with that concluded that there were a billion dollars in understated revenues, you're telling us that that report would be okay, and that would be useful for understanding whether --
Right.
But we're not saying -- we're not saying th at you can --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- the PSLRA -- the PSLRA is met, right?
It's  --it's  not the details of the report, the fact that it's from an expert. It's the details.
And as long as the details --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah, and if the details -- if it all added up.
And that's exactly  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If two plus two equaled four all the way through the report and  -- and -- and it was -- it was rigorous and robust and disclosed, then we would have a claim?
So -- so as long as those allegations were available at the time --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
--for example, for the CEO to see.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right.
So, again, that part icularity --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
-- and this Court insisting on the details --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
-- and what particularity is is so important.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
That's the legal rule we're asking for.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Kavanaugh?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So how would you summarize then the analytical or legal mistake that the Ninth Circuit committed that you think would create problems going forward for PSLRA litigation?
Yeah.
So, with respect to scienter, it blew past the what did the CEO know and when he knew it, and it's illustrated by the timing problems in this case.

We think you should write an opinion that says particularity requires answering those things, that a series of maybes is not enough. And with respect to expert opinions, the Ninth Circuit allowed an expert's opinion to substitute for particularized allegations of fact. And the legal rule should be an expert -- an expert's facts can help state a claim, but the fact that something is said by an expert by itself isn't enough.
That's what Judge Sanchez isolated in his dissent.
That is the two arguments in the cert petition and what all the amici say you should grant on.

They say this is a recurring fact pattern. People across the  country and particularly now in the Ninth Circuit are using this decision as a roadmap to get around the PLSRA's requirements. And every time a stock price -- a stock drops, you can make the same kinds of allegations, the CEO must have reviewed these reports, hire an expert to say it's a massive dollar figure.
That can happen in case after case.
Judge Friendly's warning, I think, is prophetic.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And you think the Ninth Circuit's different from other circuits if this opinion were to stand on how those kinds of cases are treated?
Absolutely.
That's what our cert petition says.
The Ninth Circuit obviously has an outsized influence on these cases just by dint of its size and where companies are located.
It's particularly dangerous to let this rule stand there, but we think, in general, you should issue a rule for the --for the entire country.

It's very much, as I was saying earlier, like Twombly. Look, it sounds -- I understand there's a whole bunch of facts, just like Twombly, pages and pages of discussion about ILECs and this and that. But, at the end of the day, this Court getting into those details and setting a rule for the entire country and giving a concrete example in that case was really important and gave guidance to litigants all across the country.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Barrett? Justice Jackson?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, Mr. Katyal, I -- I am worried about what I see as the delta between what you're asking for here today and what you asked for in your petition and what you argued in your brief, and I'm trying to reconcile the two. So I just heard you say to Justice Kavanaugh that particularity requires answering what the CEO knew and when did he know it.
That's the rule that you want us to put forward?
Those are the most important aspects, again, in a case in which it's based on those types of allegations.
You can have other cases, but --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right, right, right.
So -- okay.

And then I think, in order to reconcile that with what you have already said in your briefing, you would have to say and the only way to do that in any case of that nature is to allege the contents of the documents, because I don't know that you can get away from having said over and over again, including in your question presented, that the allegation of the contents of the documents is important.
Yeah.
So you've got to have the details of the documents.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So  --
And that includes, you know, what did  -- when I say what did the CEO know --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right.
-- the way to answer that is what are the contents of that.
You don't need to have the document itself.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, I understand that. But I --you don't need to append the document to your complaint.
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you have to allege the contents.
I mean, so --
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- your answer to Justice Kagan's hypotheticals, I think, would come out differently because she did not in her hypotheticals talk about allegations that spoke of the content of the documents.
Oh, yes, she did.
So  -- so, remember, her hypothetical as I understood it was a CEO gets documents saying our sales are really low and then goes out publicly and says our sales are very high.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That was hypo one.
That shows the delta.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And then she  -- then she -- then she -- didn't she migrate from that to  say --
And it still had --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- that the employees say these kinds of documents are circulated, we know the CEO looks at these kinds of documents, and his statements were different?
And if, you know -- and if there's details about the documents, then, yes, that meets the particularity requirement.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So they  -- so you have to have the contents of the documents?

You have to have the contents or something like the Stevelman case, in which you can infer by the CEO's conduct, like if they go and sell their stock personally or something like that, we know there's a very strong inference as to what the documents say.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know.
But your argument doesn't have the "or" in it.

Your argument says:  "Where, as here"  --and I'm reading from the summary of argument  --"a plaintiff seeks to establish scienter by relying on allegations that internal company documents contradicted public statements, the plaintiff must allege the contents of those documents."
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: "Otherwise, the allegations are insufficiently particularized because they do not describe what the documents said."
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So I was led to believe from that kind of language that really, your rule is you have to allege  --
We think that's --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- what the documents say.
Yeah.
We think that's basically right because that's based on what those documents are.
So, if the allegation is, you know, these documents say X, then you've got to have details --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And if we disagree with that, you lose, right?  Because that's the rule you're asking for.
No, I don't think we lose.

I mean, it depends on exactly how -- what you disagreed, but if you said, for example, the timing really matters, as it does here, you know, that when question, they lose every day of the week because they can't show any allegations during the class period.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Gupta.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The PSLRA demands particularity.
Everyone agrees you can't circumvent the statute with conclusory allegations or unsubstantiated expert opinions.
But  that's not what happened here. On falsity, the court of appeals' holding expressly rested on a combination of facts showing that a substantial part of gaming revenues came from crypto.

That mix included former employees' detailed accounts of internal data and meetings, the very similar analysis of the Royal Bank of Canada and Prysm, and Huang's eventual acknowledgment of the crypto hangover, which sent the stock tumbling 28 percent. On scienter too, the court of appeals relied on a mix of facts.

Executives with direct knowledge of Huang's knowledge attested that the internal data showed 60 to 70 percent of gaming revenues came from crypto, that other internal data corroborated this, and that Huang personally reviewed that data every Sunday. The Court also relied on Huang's public representations about his own knowledge.
When analysts repeatedly asked him if crypto was driving gaming sales, he called this wrong, claiming that crypto's effect was "small but not zero."  He didn't express uncertainty.

He said:  We know the market's every move, we are masters at managing our own channel. Under Tellabs and Matrixx, all of these facts must be assessed collectively and in context, not in isolation, and that is exactly what the court below did. Now the Petitioners haven't identified any legal error in that decision.

And while the cert petition and the blue brief initially seemed to propose new categorical legal rules, I think the questions from Justice Kagan, Justice Sotomayor, Justice Gorsuch, and Justice Barrett show that they have retreated to nothing more than a fact -bound application of agreed -upon legal principles. There is no need for this Court to sit as a district  court and reweigh hundreds of paragraphs anew.
If the Court does not DIG, it should instead affirm -- reaffirm Tellabs and Matrixx and affirm. I welcome the Court's questions.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I understand your argument, but what does  --what is your definition of particularity and how do you think it plays a role in your complaint?
I think particular  -- I think, actually, everyone agrees on the definition of particularity.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well  --well, what is it?

Particularity requires detail. And it's the  --it's the definition  -- it's the same concept of particularity that's come down from the common law, common formulation  in the lower courts, is you've got to have the first paragraph of a newspaper story, the who, what, why, where, when, but we would  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So how does that work in the -- what work does it do in your complaint?

So, in -- in our complaint, I think it's shot through with detail with respect to falsity, as I just recited, about all of the particular internal information within the company, the market's reaction, why  -- why there is good reason to believe that  -- that these statements were false. And with respect to scienter, you can think, I think, of the particularized allegations as the input that goes into the question that the statute asks, which is whether there's a strong inference of scienter.

And we agree with the -- the Solicitor General and I think Petitioners agree with this, that ultimately, where it cashes out is does the court have enough particularized allegations in order to assess wheth er the inference of scienter is at least as compelling as any alternative inference.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you don't think you have to go as far as an old fact pleading regime in order to sort of meet this definition of particularity?
I think that's right.
I think that the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure still apply.

I think Tellabs and Matrixx make that clear. This isn't a departure from the Federal Rules, but it is a demanding standard that requires plaintiffs to come forward with detail, detail both with respect to falsity, especially when they're alleging upon information and belief, and then detail that, as I said, allows the court to -- to  -- to determine whether or not there's a strong inference of scienter.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You say the complaint has to have enough particular allegations. As I was asking Mr. Katyal, I think we shouldn't lose sight of the fact that the PSLRA had very particular objectives in mind. And it seems to me if  --if you're -- you're using words like "enough," it's not clear to me that that's going to allow the statute to  --to be very effective. So how am I supposed to handle that conundrum?  This  -- this statute, as I said, wanted to accomplish some very specific objectives, and if enough is enough to get over it, that doesn't -- it seems to me that might  -- that the statute might have had more in mind.

Well, I think one way to look at what the statute had in mind is that it drew these -- this phrase "strong inference of scienter" from a set of cases in the Second Circuit that represented a very demanding standard and that said it's not enough to do what you could have done under Rule 9(b).
Rule 9(b), of course , said that you could -- you could generally allege the state of mind.
And the -- the Second Circuit's standard was the most demanding standard at that time.
Congress used the same words. And so that's one guide to what -- what Congress had in mind. Congress was not, however, I think, saying that circumstantial proof goes out the window.
All of those cases from the Second Circuit made clear that that kind of proof is  --is appropriate.

And Tellabs is such a case. Tellabs is a case, I think, that it's sort of a much closer case than this one, much -- sort of on the opposite end of the spectrum, where the -- the defendants were actually able to accurately say there that the plaintiffs hadn't alleged the contents of -- of the sales reports of the internal data, unlike what we have here. And if you look at the Tellabs decision on remand, I think that's a good example of how you apply these demanding pleading standards to a circumstance like that.
And there, like in this case, you were talking about demand for the company's flagship product.

The CEO was reviewing sales data constantly, even though it wasn't alleged with the kind of particularity it's alleged here, and -- and based on the total mix of allegations, it was enough to support a strong inference of scienter. And, as I said --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank  --
-- it ultimately cashes out --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, go ahead.
It ultimately cashes out on the inferences.

And so I think it's worth talking about those because we struggled in looking at the briefing to determine what are the competing inferences that my friend are  --is putting forward. And I think I can discern three, and I think those competing inferences are, first, NVIDIA wasn't tracking crypto sales; second, NVIDIA had inaccurate information or miscalculated; and, third, Huang might not have known what NVIDIA knew. And with respect to the first one, we know that the complaint is shot through with detail about how NVIDIA was tracking crypto sales.

They were doing it through multiple internal databases. There's, you know, verbatim information from internal presentations that showed that they were doing that. I think that inference is hard to credit.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Could I hear about the other two?
Sure.
The second is I think -- and I --I heard Mr. Katyal say this  --that maybe NVIDIA was trying to track crypto sales, but they had inaccurate information or miscalculated.

But we have specific data from multiple reliable sources within the company showing a consistent pattern. So we have the sales manager in China who reported that 60 to 70 percent of China sales went to miners based on the centralized sales database that Huang reviewed regularly.

And that's confirmed by internal records showing over 800,000 GeForce units sold to miners just in the second quarter of 2017 alone, which is inconsistent with Huang's public statements. We had a witness in Russia who reported that over half of the crypto sales in Russia went to crypto miners and similar reports from other markets, like India.

And these were not rough estimates. They were specific figures for NVIDIA's own tracking systems across multiple  markets, which is another way of saying that if you adopted the rule that I urge you not to adopt, we would satisfy it. And then, third, the inference is Huang might not have known what NVIDIA knew.
And I think this explanation collapses based on, you know, Huang's own statements about his own knowledge, his direct involvement.

He reviewed sales data every week, every month, and in quarterly meetings that one witness described as proctology exams because they were so detailed. The nature of his re sponses, I think, is critical here.
He, as I said earlier, when he was asked by analysts about the crypto demand, he didn't say, you know, we don't know or I don't know.
He -- he quantified the statements he was making.
And he didn't express uncertainty.
He gave very specific figures that, again  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
-- contradicted the data.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I -- may I follow up on that, Mr. Gupta?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, if we're going to treat this case as error correction, I've got some error correction kind of questions for you.
Sure.
I imagined you might have.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The first is your friend on the other side, Mr. Katyal, would say that when it comes to the falsity that you're relying predominantly on two former employees, 1 and 2, and 5's kind of the out of the picture after the Ninth Circuit's decision, for example.
And 1 is five layers below the CEO and in China.
And Number 2 left the company right at the beginning of the class period and, therefore, can't inform what happened thereafter. Would you give me your responses to those?
Sure.

A  --a few things. I mean, first of all, I think the fact that one of them left doesn't change the fact that his testimony, his -- his statements tell us in granular detail how -- what Huang's practices were for tracking this information and specifically crypto sales data.

So the only way in which it would matter that he left would be if you were to draw the inference that suddenly at the moment when the market is most focused on crypto demand and he's being asked about it at every earnings call and in every interview, that he somehow changed his practice and blinded himself to that information.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Got that.
So I don't think that really helps.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How about 1?
And then, with respect to 1, it is true that he left in December 2017.
That's into the class period.
And so he was -- I think he was the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The five  -- five layers below the CEO, they emphasized.
Well, they say that.

And, you know, that obscures the fact that he was the person in China who had the most knowledge about this issue. He was the person interfacing with the crypto mining enterprises. And we know this because, when headquarters was alarmed about the exploding crypto demand, FE 1 is the person they tasked with looking at all of the data and making this presentation that went to headquarters that showed --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, he's the guy who -- who knows the data, knows what goes into the sales reports that he sends up the chain.
And then you've got the other guy saying and the CEO looked at these sales reports with -- with great interest routinely.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: At least up until the time I left.
Yes, that's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
All right.
Okay. I got it. On -- on the -- on the second question, on -- on --on the expert report, another fact-bound error correction.
Prysm relied on, as -- as we've heard, a proprietary model that was undisclosed.
Is that a problem?  Why  -- why isn't that a problem?
I think that's  just an inaccurate characterization of the report, Your Honor.
This  --there was no model.
This is -- basically, what Prysm was doing was math.
It was taking publicly avail able figures and doing some multiplication.
And the math, by the way, is the same math that the Royal --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Pretty expensive math I have to guess, but  -- (Laughter.)
Well, you know, it's the same math that the Royal Bank of Canada did.
And you heard from my friend that there's nothing about the Royal Bank of Canada's calculations.
So I just do want to point out to the Court that the Royal Ban k of Canada's report is in the record.
It's at Docket 124-31.
And so you can see that the math there is the same. And this isn't terribly fancy math.
It's taking what's called the hashrate, which they haven't contested.
That's the  -- the measure of the output on these crypto blockchain networks.
And they  -- and --and Prysm did  a very conservative estimate.
They only took the three most popular blockchain networks that required GPU processing, and then they applied a market share number.
And I think, when he says proprietary model, what he's talking about is one of the three measures of market share that they used, but that was a firm that NVIDIA itself used for market share data.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right, right.
But they also had two other measures of market share data, and one was based on the internal document that FE 1 prepared, that slide.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That 69 percent?
Right.
Exactly.
And so --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you had to -- keep going, sorry.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you want to finish that up, that might turn out to be useful for us, so go ahead.
Well, I mean, I think that was the main  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's it?  You got it?
--thing I wanted to say about that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
Thank you.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you had to summarize why you think Judge Sanchez was wrong, how would you -- how would you summarize that?

I think that Judge Sanchez, with all respect to Judge Sanchez, just wa sn't characterizing the  -- the plaintiffs' complaint or actually the majority's opinion fairly because he -- he seemed to think that the expert report was the linchpin of everything, and the plaintiffs only put forward the expert report as confirmatory.
