They were going above and beyond because the PSLRA is demanding and this was sort of belt-and- suspenders, but if you take the expert report out, it doesn't change the picture of -- of falsity in any dramatic way.

It's merely confirmatory. And so I understand that, you know, the Court may have been persuaded to grant certiorari based on that characterization, but I think the characterization just doesn't hold up.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, Judge Sanchez thought that the majority had not paid sufficient attention to opposing inferences.
You have laid out the allegations from which you claim one can infer that Huang knew that what he said was false, but under Tellabs, that had to be weighed against competing interests.
And Judge -- as I understood Judge Sanchez's opinion, he said that was not done, and he pointed in particular to Figure F. So what is wrong with that?
Yeah.
I'm  -- I'm glad I have the opportunity to address Figure F because this is the --this is the basis for my friend's statement that the complaint "eats itself."  And I think that's just not so.

The  -- he's referring to the slide that's at page 62 from the internal China presentation, and the data there actually falsifies Mr. Huang's public statements. So the three bars there on the bar chart -- and I realize I sound like I'm in a district court argument  -- but these three bar -- bars are reflecting the sales for the second quarter, the second quarter of the Fiscal Year 2018, but this is in 2017.
And it show s that the majority of sales are -- to crypto miners are GeForce GPU units.

And it also is inconsistent with the public statement that -- that Mr. Huang made about that quarter, when asked about the second quarter earnings, that the SKU was capturing the majority of the sales.
That isn't true. And then immediately after the period of this slide, the public data released by NVIDIA shows that the OEM segment, the crypto SKU segment, dropped dramatically.
And so it's not consistent with the idea that there's a  trend in -- in -- in that direction.

It's not consistent with the statements that Mr. Huang made publicly. So this -- this slide is actually  -- this is the thing that they pointed to to help them, but it actually shows in fairly granular detail much more than the PSLRA demands because we don't have to prove our case in a summary judgment-like fashion, but it shows that the statements were false.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, Judge  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's a  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- Judge Sanchez said that he thought that the slide showed that the crypto SKU was drawing sales away.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Among miners, it was drawing sales away from the GeForce GP -- GPU.
Is that incorrect?
I --you know, I don't -- don't -- don't  think it is.

And I think this goes to some of the -- what I heard from my friend is addressing a conspiracy theory that we didn't advance and are not advancing. We are not saying that the crypto SKU didn't capture some of the sales to miners, and we're not saying that the company engaged in accounting fraud in misstating those revenues.

It stated those revenues. The problem was that it equated crypto demand with the line item regarding the SKU, which led analysts to be misled consistently to think  that there wasn't crypto demand that was driving the GeForce sales when, in fact, it was.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So I'm focused a little bit on the demands of particularity at this stage. You -- you -- in part of your response to Justice Alito right there, you sa id we don't have to prove our case in a summary judgment-like fashion. And -- and that's what I thought, but I'm just wondering whether that's actually the case.

The Chief Justice asks, well, what was the point of the PR --P -- PSLRA?  And  --and is it possible that the PSLRA was really, with its particularity requirement, demanding that plaintiffs have the kinds of evidence that would be necessary to demonstrate the inferences that they would want the Court to draw?
So I think this Court in Tellabs rejected exactly that argument.
And I don't understand my friend to be asking you to overrule that portion of Tellabs.

So Tellabs holds that we don't have to meet a summary judgment-like standard or present more proof than we would need to present at trial. Now I think, if this were a district court and we were having a summary judgment argument, I'd like our chances because we have quite a lot of evidence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And I appreciate that, but I -- I guess I'm just trying to understand what the standard is.

What  --so, if you don't have to demonstrate through the presentation of evidence that your inferences are correct or that you have enough evidence to show a jury that your inferences are correct, then what is the work of particularity? I mean, your -- your colleague on the other side suggests that you do have to have enough detail about the contents of the documents in order to do something.
But I can't separate that out from saying you have to have the documents themselves --
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- in some way.
I --I think this -- this colloquy shows the  -- the wisdom of the Court's consistent refusal to adopt bright-line rules.
I -- I acknowledge that there are going to be some cases where the plaintiffs' failure to allege the contents of documents is going to be fatal.

But there are going to be a great many cases in which there's a holistic analysis of all of the -- the mix of facts where that's not necessary, and I think, actually, Tellabs on remand and Matrixx are two such cases.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, counsel. If I could just pick up on that point.
In requiring particularity, the PSLRA was at least raising the bar when you talk about, you know, you have to have some evidence of this or that.
Congress went out and saw a real problem there and wanted to do something about it.

So the idea that, oh, you're going to have varying levels of particularity with respect to the evidence is kind of a hard standard to apply. I mean, if it is just, oh, you look  -- you know, it's a case-by-case basis, and we're going to have to wait for 25 or however many years until some general rule is distilled, it doesn't seem to me that the statute is doing what they  meant it to do.

Well, I -- I think the statute is doing what they meant it to do, and I think the proof is in the -- in the lower court jurisprudence. I think, if you look at all of the -- the cases cited in the cert petition, we don't really have any quarrel with those cases.
They are engaging in a -- a fairly fact-bound analysis in each of those cases about whether the rules of particularity are met. And it's not easy.
The standard is not easy to meet.

This is  -- my friend is right when he said that this is a  --a standard that is different from the  -- the typical standard, and that's why you get complaints that take up as much of the Joint Appendix as this complaint does.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I'm not sure what they were looking for is verbosity.
I mean -- (Laughter.)
Fair.
Fair.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: --I hope not anyway.
Yes, and, in fact, there are some cases where the courts are saying your complaint is too long.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right.
And -- and, you know, so I think it's not just length.

It has to be detailed, and it has to be detail that is sufficient, as -- as the Court said in Tellabs, to -- to negate or at least to show that there as  --the inferences are as compelling as any competing inference.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank -- thank you. Justice Thomas, anything further? Justice Alito?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you think that motive has any role to play in the analysis of scienter?  I know you don't have to prove motive.
Do you think it's relevant?
Yes.
I think this Court has said that it's -- it's relevant but not necessary. And --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, if the  -- I mean, if the real figure is one and a half billion dollars or over a billion dollars and Mr. Huang says no, it's a hundred million --
Mm-hmm.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- what motive could he have for making a statement that is so far off and that is, if you are correct, if the over a billion dollars figure is correct, is surely going to be -- going to come to light with severe consequences?
That's the argument my friends make.
And I think you could have made --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
Well, what's wrong with it?
You could have made exactly the same argument in Tellabs, where it was pretty clear to everyone that nobody wanted this product and the new product wasn't going to suffice.

You could have said very much the same thing in Matrixx, where it was clear that this nose spray caused people to lose their sense of smell, and -- and everyone was starting to figure that out. In this case, however, I think that, you know, Huang might have thought what a lot of people think when they're carrying out a fraudulent scheme, in a Ponzi scheme, for example, which is that people might not find out and the reality might not catch up with them. And --and just imagine that the crypto crash had happened a bit later.
NVIDIA is now a company whose sales rely on  --on the need for these chips for artificial intelligence.

If that artificial intelligence demand had arrived a little bit earlier and the crypto crash had happened a little bit later, this fraud would not have been recognized and there would not have been the crash, and so he may have been relying on precisely that kind of hypothetical scenario.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So your -- your answer -- I was struck by the SG's answer, well, it's like a Ponzi scheme.
And  -- and you really don't have a better explanation?  It's a Ponzi scheme?
Well, no.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This  --
--I don't think it's like  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- gigantic company with highly sophisticated officers is engaging in a Ponzi scheme?  All right.
Maybe.

I don't think it's -- I don't think we're saying that it was a Ponzi scheme, and I don't think that's how I understood the Solicitor General's brief as well. It's that you could say the same thing in a Ponzi scheme case, and you could say the same thing in many securities fraud cases, including the two cases that this Court has had under the PSLRA.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Sotomayor?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Counsel, I see two purposes  -- there may be others -- to the PSLRA particular -- particularity requirement.
It has two purposes, I think:  to ensure that defendants know exactly what to defend against and to prevent frivolous lawsuits. The allegations in this complaint are pretty clear.
They have to defend against whether crypto mining was driving their business during the --the class period, corr ect?
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And to defend against it, all they have to do is show the sales records that all of these employees say exist, correct?
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Katyal seemed to suggest in his responses to one of my questions, I think it was, that the SEC has those records.
Are you aware of the SEC -- you don't have them?
I don't have them.

You know, I think --I think the S  -- it's important to understand that the SEC's enforcement action  --and, you know, the government can speak to this -- was just about -- focused on the -- the disclosures made to the SEC.
And that's not uncommon.
That's understandable.
They were focused on what NVIDIA had told the government.
So it wasn't the subject matter of this case, which spans a whole range of statements made over a longer period of time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What happened to that SEC case?
The SEC -- NVIDIA settled the SEC case.
They were fined.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But no admission of liability?
They did not admit liability, but I think, you know, attached to the red brief is the -- is the cease-and-desist order from the SEC.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And just to be clear, you don't have whatever records the SEC got?  If they got the sales records or not, you don't know?
We --we do not have those.
We would need discovery.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The government would probably tell us that.
Okay.
Thank you.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Kagan?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If I just could go back to the questions that Justice Alito asked you, because it strikes me that, from your answer, the Ponzi scheme is actually a bad term for what you're suggesting.
A Ponzi scheme is like you're -- you're -- you're never going to get caught up.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it's just dishonesty after dishonesty after dishonesty to try to hide that fact.
But you're not suggesting that.
You're actually saying that if things had worked out a little bit differently  --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- in the market for crypto and --and in the  -- and in other markets that NVIDIA was involved in, NVIDIA is now the company that's sending the stock market into the stratosphere, we would never have known about this.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You know?  So Mr. Huang might have been making a pretty good bet here.
Exactly.
And  --and your answer is much better than mine was.
Right. Exactly. (Laughter.)

I --I think that there's a difference between someone who's carrying on a scheme where it's inevitable that they're going to get caught and someone who's rationally calculating that the market might not catch up to what they're saying.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm sorry, Justice Gorsuch? Justice Kavanaugh?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How much money is at stake in this case, in other words, if you were to prevail ultimately in the class?
Not as much as it might seem because -- well, I don't want the Court to get the impression that this enormous delta of -- of sales is what's at issue.
What would be at issue would be we would have to show lost causation and materiality --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What are you seeking? Like, if you ran the table, what -- what are you seeking roughly?
Well, I don't know what the numbers are, Your Honor, but I think, you know --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Rough?
-- people were harmed.
If the -- if the -- you know, because they were -- imagine somebody whose retirement savings were in NVIDIA and they sold the stock at the time of the crash and they -- you know, they were harmed.
Now there would be maybe other people who rode it out and weren't harmed and -- and, you know, don't need -- don't need any relief.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So you don't have any idea how much you would be seeking?
I don't know the answer to that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
And the concern, I think, raised by the amici is the fraud by hindsight that you've heard Mr. Katyal, and I just want to --
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- give you a chance to respond.

The idea is of the effects on the American economy if businesses -- anytime a stock price falls, you can get an expert and you can get past a motion to dismiss, and that has a  -- as you read in the amici, you know all this, but has a significant effect on the American economy and that while it's painful for us to get into th e facts and have to actually, you know, dig into the facts, the Ninth Circuit opinion, so the amici say, is a blueprint for getting past the motion to dismiss in a way that's contrary to what Congress thought and will have negative effects on the American economy and that it's our role to make sure that we have policed the lines Congress drew so that the economy is not harmed.
So  --
So there are a few questions in there.

I think, first of all, with respect to your role, I think the Court's role is -- you know, Congress's role is to balance these competing event -- objectives about needing meritorious suits to -- to discipline capital markets and ensure that there aren't frivolous suits that a re a drain on the economy.
Congress struck that balance with this statute.

They wanted meritorious cases to go forward like this one. They did not want the kind of thing that Judge Friendly was describing -- I think my friend is right about this  -- where you had what was called fraud by hindsight, where, you know, a stock goes down, the day later, you know, plaintiffs' lawyers who are not representing institutional investors file a lawsuit without any investigation. Those kinds of cases where, you know, they're looking for a theory of fraud without any information, those kinds of things are the -- are what the PSLRA was intended to root out and appropriately so because Congress did strike a balance.

Congress recognized that there is a value to having private securities litigation as a supplement to public enforcement to ensure that our capital markets are the best in the world, that they are efficient, that they are honest, that people can rely on our stock markets.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If Judge Sanchez's opinion had been the majority opinion, would you have sought cert?
I probably would have been very upset, but I probably would have counseled my clients that this is a fact-bound disagreement --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Really? (Laughter.)
--about settled standards.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I wouldn't bind yourself like that, but anyway, thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice Barrett? Justice Jackson? Thank you, counsel.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Ms. Sinzdak.

Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: To resolve this case, the Court does not need to create any new one-size-fits-all rules. Instead, it can simply reiterate a few basic principles that flow from the plain text of the PSLRA, and the good news is I think we're all agreed on those basic legal principles. So, first, as to scienter, the PSLRA requires a plaintiff to plead enough particularized facts to create a strong inference of scienter. Particularity means detail.
But the particularity requirement doesn't say anything about what kind of details the plaintiff has to plead.
So long as she pleads enough details to make the inference of scienter at least as likely as any competing innocent inference, then she has cleared the PSLRA's bar.
And we think that happened here. Second, as to expert reports, the PSLRA does not mention them at all.
So they're neither disfavored, nor are they preferred.
It's just that the same basic standards apply.
So, if a plaintiff is relying on facts drawn from an expert report, they have to be pleaded with particularity.

And if the plaintiff is relying on a belief, it's making information and belief pleading, then it needs to plead the particularized facts supporting that -- that opinion, that belief. Again, we think that's the standard the Ninth Circuit applied here, and so all the Court needs to do is reiterate these principles and affirm. I welcome the Court's questions.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you think particularity is used in the same way it's used in Rule 9(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure?
Yes.
I think it looks like it was taken from that, Congress was taking it through -- from that.

And I -- I think that's a good point perhaps to what the Chief Justice was asking about before, what did the PSLRA do. The -- Rule -- Rule 9(b) says that you have to plead facts with  --with particularity.
It creates an exception for scienter.
And then the PSLRA effectively takes that exception away.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So I  --I take it you think the PSLRA was intended to do a good bit more than simply keep out frivolous lawsuits?
I -- I think it definitely was intended to keep out frivolous lawsuits.
I think there was  a --a competing intent to -- to ensure that -- that meritorious lawsuits would go through.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.
But my question was, do you think it was intended to do more than simply keep out frivolous lawsuits?
In  -- in --I think that was the primary purpose, but I may not be understanding your question.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, you said it was designed to ensure adequate allegation of scienter, that it imposed a  --a heightened particularity standard.
All those other things that you listed.
Sure.

I think I was thinking of those as means to the end of keeping out frivolous litigation and -- and of raising the pleading standard, but  --but, yes, I certainly think that those were the specific things that Congress did within the PSLRA.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Ms. Sinzdak, so let's say that we don't adopt for scienter this  -- this bright-line rule.

Mr. Katyal suggested that for the comparative standard at least as cogent and compelling as the alternative, that the Ninth Circuit, while parroting the rule, didn't adequately apply it. It seems to me that if we rejected the bright-line rule, we could either affirm, as you suggest, or perhaps  --I'm not saying we do -- but if we agreed with Mr. Katyal, we could vacate and remand and say you stated the right standard, but you didn't adequately apply it.
Does the government really have a dog in that fight and, if so, why?
Not really, except that we -- we do think that the Ninth Circuit correctly applied the standard here.

And what we wouldn't want is there to be confusion because, if the Court reiterates the standard but then remands, there might be some suggestion that the Ninth Circuit did something wrong, and courts might be a little bit confused about what it is that they did wrong. And, again, we think that if you look at the Ninth Circuit's decision, it really was fulfilling this requirement.

And I think, you know, 42a is the place where  --where the  -- the -- the -- the Ninth Circuit sort of talks about all of the different things that it relied on to find scienter here, and I do think it articulates the Tellabs standard  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
--and applies it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you think that the settlement with the SEC has any legal relevance here?

I think only marginally in that the SEC did make findings, including, you know, the find  -- this is a finding that -- that NVIDIA had information indicating that crypto mining was a significant factor in the year-over-year growth revenue from the sale of GPUs. So the SEC made that finding, but NVIDIA did not admit that finding.
So this isn't in the nature of an acknowledgment.
I think, you know, it's one fact that might make it slightly more plausible.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, would it be admissible if the case were tried?
I -- I -- it would not be admissible in terms of any -- it's not a -- it's not the -- pardon me -- it's not acknowledgment as to that issue.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I just wondered why you mentioned it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Just  -- just to dirty up
Oh, in the  -- in the -- in our brief?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In your brief, yeah.
I think primarily because the parties had mentioned it, and we just wanted to be honest about it.
But I think you'll note we mentioned it in our statement.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
We didn't talk about it in the argument.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Katyal then  -- if -- I may have totally misunderstood him, but I thought he said that whatever he gave to the SEC proved his case and not his opponent's case.
The only publicly available information about the settlement is what we have -- what was attached to the red brief and what -- it's in Westlaw.
It's cited at page 7 of our brief.
What the SEC had in terms of documents is  -- is --is not publicly available. I'm not sure whether Mr. Katyal was -- was talking about what his clients gave them.
I -- I just -- I don't know that.
It's not publicly available.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But whatever he said the documents showed is not anything that you're prepared to say they showed?
No.
What I  --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Other than that  --what you read?
Yes, excuse me.
I -- I -- I completely agree.
So what the SEC's findings are are embodied in this settlement agreement that --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You answered the Chief by saying there was one purpose, frivolous lawsuits. I thought the  --there was a second purpose, which was to ensure that defendants knew what they were defending against.
That -- that's right.
It is also --so there's  -- there's -- I think the -- the --some of the amicus briefs on Respondents' side point out that, in general, particularity requirements are to assist with notice.

And so I think that's there. And -- and maybe just, Chief -- Mr. Chief Justice, to return to your question, if what we're talking about is the frivolous, that it's more than --this is more -- this is doing more than Rule 11, I would certainly agree with you there.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Counsel, you've end -- you've ended answering me, right?
Oh, sure.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If the dissent had been the majority, what problems would have been created going forward from your perspective?
If the dissent had been the majority, I -- I think, honestly, what we have is a -- is a disagreement on the facts that I -- I --I think --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So that goes to your answer to Justice Barrett's question it sounds like then?
Yes.

I mean, I -- I -- I think that it would have a profound effect on this case, but I'm not sure that it would set bad law going forward. I think that -- just to -- to touch on a few things very briefly that had already come up, in terms of how to handle expert reports, Justice Alito, I think you said that it may be difficult for district courts to know what to do with these very technical sets of facts that you'll find in expert reports.

That's going to be the same problem if they're not in expert reports, and they might even be more confusing because I think, if you have plaintiffs' lawyers trying to articulate a bunch of highly technical facts, it might come out a little bit more garbled.

So I don't  think that's a particular reason to adopt a special  --a special rule, and the PSLRA does not. Justice Kavanaugh, I think you asked about the Ninth Circuit applying di fferent rules, and I really don't think that they are.

And the best evidence perhaps of this is that Anderson, the case that Petitioners cite and rely on as doing it right, is repeatedly relying on Ninth Circuit precedent. And I'd also note that the district court decision, which, again, Petitioners are relying on, that also is repeatedly relying on Ninth Circuit decisions.

So I don't think this is a case where the court of appeal s has gone rogue and is doing anything different than the other -- the other courts of appeals here. And in terms of the slide, the main thing that I want to say there is that the -- the Ninth Circuit did address the slide.

I think that, you know, this Court is not a court of  -- of --of factual analysis, but if you're concerned that the Ninth Circuit just wasn't doing things, the  -- there's many pages of analysis from 48a to 55a explaining that they were examining that.
And  -- and, similarly, there's many pages of analysis examining the detailed factual allegations underlying the expert report.
That's 20a to 22a. So unless there are further questions?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Anything further? Thank you, counsel. Rebuttal, Mr. Katyal.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Five points. First, Mr. Gupta said that particularity requires detail.
We quite agree.
Yet the Ninth Circuit said that this complaint had enough detail. This is why you need to reverse.
It's dangerous to say this amount of detail is enough for a complaint. That's not a change in our position.
They're the ones -- I'll explain that in a moment -- but they're the ones changing their position.

They are running away from the Ninth Circuit. The Ninth Circuit's decision said that the CEO "would have reflected their expert opinion" and does not engage in any sort of comparative ana lysis. 42a is not a comparative analysis.
They -- the Ninth Circuit never even bothered answering our competing hypothesis, which was the pricing explanation.
You have to reverse that.

And as the amici say, otherwise, you're letting circuit courts let decisions  --let litigants provide these cases and state a claim without a comparative inquiry. And you certainly have to reject their new idea that these employees are enough because they don't indicate when the CEO knew something.
Was it after or before that watershed SKU event?  Nothing said that they -- they do say that the CEO actually saw the data at the time.
The best they have is a video that was taken from 2012, well before the class period. And Mr. -- and Judge Sanchez explains at 62a why that slide is so devastating.
And he also explains at 82a why not a single employee ever said the CEO saw anything damaging during the class period. You can't let this stand for the reasons the amici say.

Congress in the Reform Act, as the Chief Justice indicated, wanted to stop lawsuits like this, lawsuits that allow fraud by  -- fraud by hindsight. Second, Justice Jackson, our rule is that if they are relying on documents, they then need to allege the contents.
If they aren't relying on those documents, they don't have to.

And I understood Justice Kagan's second hypothetical to be relying not on internal documents and, if so, they don't need to provide the details. Now our rule has always been the same. It's the rule found, for example, at page 31 of our brief:  When a plaintiff omits the most critical aspect of allegations about a company's internal documents, the contents of  those documents that support the plaintiff's claim, the allegation cannot be particularized, citing the Fifth Circuit case. The Solicitor General's rule -- rule at page 18 of their brief is very similar.
We think both of those would require reversal. Fourth, picking up on the Chief  --or excuse me.
Third, picking up on the Chief Justice's point, Congress in the Reform Act said maybe is not good enough, that scienter requires a strong inference.
And yet, at the end of the day, all you've heard from my friend on the other side is a series of maybes.
Maybe there were documents that contradicted the statements about dependence on -- on crypto.

Maybe Mr. Huang looked at those documents. Maybe he looked at them before his public statements. And maybe he deliberately misstated sales. Each of those is just a percentage chance, and taken together, they don't come close to being the kind of scienter inference that is at least as compel -- compelling as the competing alternative. Judge Sanchez on this point is devastating, as Justice Alito was picking up on.
Why would it make any sense for a CEO to act this way? In the context of the Reform Act, maybe doesn't cut it.
And that's especially true here when their whole theory about motive makes no sense whatsoever.
Mr. Huang is not running a Ponzi scheme. We're talking about one of the most respected CEOs of a dramatically important company.
And there is nothing that ever answers why he would act this way when he is saying time and again the pricing data shows that they can't track end users. Finally, this gets a little abstract.
Let me make it concrete.
You heard today and the red brief at page 13 says Mr. Huang "continuously tracked the inventory in the channel."  That statement illustrates why details matter.
Consider the who. Mr. Huang never said that statement was made by someone else.
Consider the when.

It was made in 2007, before cryptocurrency was even invented. This is a good illustration of why details matter, why what the district court did here by going allegation by allegation and interrogating it to make sure that the details support the story are there. That's what allows a court to get past the competing inference that Tellabs requires.

That's precisely what the Ninth Circuit  had missing every day -- on every page of its analysis. Never did they deal with the competing explanation that the company offered that prices were remaining high because of independent actions by retailers.
Had they done that, if the complaint had provided that level of detail, that would be one thing.
This complaint doesn't.
And that's why it's so dangerous, as the amici say, to let a case like this lay and pick  -- and allow litigants in the future to pick up and get past state a claim barriers.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
